articles.headline: Remember All Those Passwords? No Need
articles.snippet: Dashlane is a dedicated password memorization program stuffed with features, and it’s free.
articles.abstract: Dashlane is a dedicated password memorization program stuffed with features, and it’s free.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If you want to avoid having your identity stolen, use long passwords that contain digits, punctuation and no recognizable words. Make up a different password for every Web site. And change all of your passwords every 30 days.”

articles.headline: Countries Seek Entrepreneurs From Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: As Congress debates immigration, countries like Canada and Australia are trying to lure foreign entrepreneurs. But there’s only one place they want to be.
articles.abstract: As Congress debates immigration, countries like Canada and Australia are trying to lure foreign entrepreneurs. But there’s only one place they want to be.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A bold new billboard looms over U.S. 101, the highway that runs through the heart of the global technology industry. “H-1b problems?” it reads. “Pivot to Canada.”

articles.headline: Publishers Tell of Disputes With Apple on E-Book Prices
articles.snippet: The Justice Department has claimed that the publishers used Apple as a conduit to communicate with each other; Apple lawyers have sought to portray the conversations as normal business proceedings.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department has claimed that the publishers used Apple as a conduit to communicate with each other; Apple lawyers have sought to portray the conversations as normal business proceedings.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an e-mail to her boss, Leslie Moonves, Carolyn K. Reidy, the chief executive of Simon & Schuster, dismissed an Apple executive as a “minion.”

articles.headline: Debt Deal in Alabama Will Cost JPMorgan
articles.snippet: Ultimately, JPMorgan Chase will have given up nearly $1.6 billion as a result of its dealings with Jefferson County.
articles.abstract: Ultimately, JPMorgan Chase will have given up nearly $1.6 billion as a result of its dealings with Jefferson County.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under the deal to settle the bankruptcy of Jefferson County, Ala., firms that invested in its distressed debt will have the most to gain, JPMorgan Chase will face a big loss, and residents will be wondering whether there will be any relief for them.

articles.headline: As Investors Bail Out, SAC Shows a Brave Face
articles.snippet: SAC Capital Advisors, which is caught up in an insider trading investigation, told employees in an e-mail that it was stable despite a surge in investor withdrawals.
articles.abstract: SAC Capital Advisors, which is caught up in an insider trading investigation, told employees in an e-mail that it was stable despite a surge in investor withdrawals.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAC Capital Advisors, the besieged hedge fund owned by the billionaire stock picker Steven A. Cohen, has told its employees that it will survive a wave of investor withdrawals during the government’s intensifying investigation into possible insider trading at the firm.

articles.headline: Financial Fears Gain Credence as Unrest Shakes Turkey
articles.snippet: While Turkey’s economy has grown swiftly over the past decade, the recent protests in Taksim Square are signaling that economic trouble could be approaching.
articles.abstract: While Turkey’s economy has grown swiftly over the past decade, the recent protests in Taksim Square are signaling that economic trouble could be approaching.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It is not often that the rock-throwing street protester and the seasoned bond investor see eye to eye.

articles.headline: From ‘a Child of the House’ to Longest-Serving Member
articles.snippet: Representative John D. Dingell Jr., Democrat of Michigan, is about to set a new standard with 57 years, 5 months and 26 days of House service.
articles.abstract: Representative John D. Dingell Jr., Democrat of Michigan, is about to set a new standard with 57 years, 5 months and 26 days of House service.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In an institution where seniority has long been prized, Representative John D. Dingell Jr. of Michigan is about to set a new standard with 57 years, 5 months and 26 days of House service — a remarkable tenure that spans more than a quarter of the existence of Congress.

articles.headline: I.M.F. Concedes Major Missteps in Bailout of Greece
articles.snippet: The International Monetary Fund released an internal report that sharply criticizes its first bailout program for Greece, saying it seriously underestimated the severity of the country’s downturn.
articles.abstract: The International Monetary Fund released an internal report that sharply criticizes its first bailout program for Greece, saying it seriously underestimated the severity of the country’s downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund released an internal report on Wednesday that sharply criticizes its first bailout program for Greece, the latest in a series of partial mea culpas as the fund reassesses the austerity that it has insisted on for ailing, debt-plagued economies.

articles.headline: On Newsstands, Allure of the Film Actress Fades
articles.snippet: Film stars are no longer the reader magnets they once were, so magazines are turning to TV actors, reality stars and musicians.
articles.abstract: Film stars are no longer the reader magnets they once were, so magazines are turning to TV actors, reality stars and musicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pity the poor Hollywood film stars: they can’t open movies the way they used to and now they can’t sell magazines.

articles.headline: In Personnel Appointments, Obama Takes Assertive Tack
articles.snippet: Recent unapologetic selections reflect a conclusion in the West Wing that when it comes to choosing personnel, the president can never satisfy Republicans.
articles.abstract: Recent unapologetic selections reflect a conclusion in the West Wing that when it comes to choosing personnel, the president can never satisfy Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s defiant selection of Susan E. Rice as his new national security adviser on Wednesday underscored the newly assertive approach he has taken to appointments ever since he abandoned a potential cabinet nominee named Susan E. Rice.

articles.headline: China Seen in Push to Gain Technology Insights
articles.snippet: As China seeks to become more competitive, scientists on the job in the United States are being asked to share technology data.
articles.abstract: As China seeks to become more competitive, scientists on the job in the United States are being asked to share technology data.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — A government-financed research institute in the Pearl River Delta here boasts an impressive range of specialties, from robotics to nanomedicine to magnetic resonance imaging.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Didi Kirsten Tatlow

articles.headline: Obama’s Choices Reflect Change in Foreign Tone
articles.snippet: President Obama named Susan E. Rice and Samantha Power to major national security posts on Wednesday, promoting two outspoken voices for humanitarian intervention.
articles.abstract: President Obama named Susan E. Rice and Samantha Power to major national security posts on Wednesday, promoting two outspoken voices for humanitarian intervention.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama named Susan E. Rice and Samantha Power to major national security posts on Wednesday, promoting two outspoken voices for humanitarian intervention on a foreign policy team known for its deep caution in dealing with conflicts abroad.

articles.headline: U.S. Confirms That It Gathers Online Data Overseas
articles.snippet: The federal government has secretly taken information on foreigners overseas for years from companies like Google, Facebook and Apple, the director of national intelligence confirmed.
articles.abstract: The federal government has secretly taken information on foreigners overseas for years from companies like Google, Facebook and Apple, the director of national intelligence confirmed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government has been secretly collecting information on foreigners overseas for nearly six years from the nation’s largest Internet companies like Google, Facebook and, most recently, Apple, in search of national security threats, the director of national intelligence confirmed Thursday night.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Edward Wyatt and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Down So Long, It Looks Like Up to the Euro Zone
articles.snippet: After nearly six years of crisis, the bar for good economic news has sunk so low that any sign of deceleration in the tailspin has become cause for celebration.
articles.abstract: After nearly six years of crisis, the bar for good economic news has sunk so low that any sign of deceleration in the tailspin has become cause for celebration.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — This is what passes for good economic news in Europe: Spain just added 265 jobs.
